concern: As the title says my roommate doesn’t clean up after themself. Now our room isn’t a complete disaster and it’s mainly their side (plus our bathroom but it’s kinda 70/30 on who makes the most mess of it) but they just don’t really clean up. They have cups and cans and bottles all over their nightstand and desk and have even had a cup under their bed on the dresser before, and they’re never empty either. They also go home every weekend so they don’t really have dishes or real food here so they’re all Starbucks and Dunkin’ cups, so half full coffees just sitting there separating for weeks as they go home and come back. They do sorta clean it after a few weeks, I’ve seen them bag up the cups and other garbage, but they don’t take it out. They have bags full of garbage in the corner on their side of the room and our rooms not big so it’s starting to creep towards our closet almost in the way of it. As for the bathroom they leave hair everywhere and I know it’s theirs and not mine because it’s their little rubber bands with the hair. Now like I said I am also at fault for the the bathroom being messy but I try to keep it somewhat clean by taking out the garbage and have cleaned the shower drain but they don’t even try to clean up a bit. I don’t know how they don’t get embarrassed when they have a friend over or even just with me being here. I get embarrassed having 2 cans on my desk and a few dirty forks or spoons for a few days because I’m too tired to wash them yet. Otherwise they’re a good roommate it’s just they never clean. I should also say they had a single room last year so it definitely feels like part of the reason since they would be used to not sharing a space but I want to have friends over and I’m embarrassed for my roommate. I don’t really know how to tell them to take their garbage out without sounding like a bitch and I already accepted I’m gonna be cleaning our bathroom alone.

dialogue_total.statement: Welcome to our session today. I'm here to listen without judgment and help you explore any thoughts or concerns that have been on your mind. Take your time, and feel free to share whatever comes to you naturally.
Thanks for being here. I’ve been feeling pretty frustrated lately about some stuff with my roommate, and I just don’t know how to handle it without making things weird.
It sounds like you're feeling stuck between wanting to address the issue and not wanting to create tension with your roommate. Can you tell me more about what's been causing this frustration?

Yeah, it’s just really getting to me how messy things are, and I feel like I’m stuck dealing with it. I don’t want to come off as rude or start a fight, but it’s hard to ignore when it’s right there in our shared space.

That sounds like a really tough spot to be in, feeling like you have to choose between your own comfort and the potential for conflict with your roommate. It's totally understandable that you're feeling frustrated and stuck. Can you tell me more about what kind of messes you're dealing with, and how they've been affecting you?

Honestly, it’s just the constant clutter and lack of effort on their part that’s getting to me. It makes me feel uneasy in my own space, like I can’t fully relax or have people over without being embarrassed.

It sounds like the clutter and lack of effort from your roommate is really affecting your sense of comfort and pride in your space. What do you think would make the biggest difference for you, in terms of how you'd like things to be different?

Honestly, I think if they just picked up after themselves a bit and took out their trash regularly, it’d make a huge difference. I’d feel so much better not having to see the mess piling up or worry about it when I want to have friends over.

It sounds like having your roommate take responsibility for their belongings and cleaning up after themselves would go a long way in alleviating your stress and making you feel more comfortable in your shared space. Do you think there's a way to bring this up with your roommate in a way that feels respectful and open to finding a solution together?

Yeah, I think I could try to talk to them about it, maybe just casually mention how the mess is kinda stressing me out and suggest we both keep things tidier. I’m just nervous about how they’ll take it, you know, since I don’t want to seem like I’m nagging or starting drama.

That’s a thoughtful approach, and it sounds like you’re already considering how to bring this up in a way that’s respectful and collaborative. What do you think might happen if you were to have that conversation with your roommate, and what could help you feel more confident in bringing it up?

I guess I’m worried they might get defensive or think I’m being too picky, and I don’t want things to get awkward between us since we’ve been getting along otherwise. Having some kinda backup plan, like knowing I can just focus on my side if they don’t take it well, might help me feel a bit braver about starting the convo.

That's a really good point, and it makes sense that you want to maintain your positive relationship with your roommate. Having a backup plan can be a great way to feel more confident when approaching a difficult conversation. What do you think your backup plan could look like?

I think my backup plan could just be sticking to keeping my own space clean and maybe setting some clear boundaries, like not letting their stuff creep into my area. I’d probably also just keep focusing on my own habits and not stress too much about their side if they don’t wanna change, ya know?

That sounds like a solid plan that prioritizes your own well-being while still maintaining a respectful boundary. It might also help to approach the conversation with your roommate as a team effort, focusing on how keeping a tidy space could benefit both of you in terms of reducing stress and making your living environment more enjoyable. How do you think you could frame the conversation to emphasize that teamwork aspect?

I think I could start by saying something like, hey, I’ve noticed our space gets a bit cluttered and it’s kinda stressing me out, so maybe we can work together to keep it tidier. Like, just throw out a casual idea of both of us picking up after ourselves more, ya know, so it’s not just one of us dealing with it and we both feel better about the room.

That approach sounds thoughtful and collaborative, and framing it as a team effort can help your roommate feel included rather than criticized. It might also be helpful to anticipate potential responses or concerns they might have, so you can address them proactively and show that you're open to finding a solution that works for both of you.

I guess I could think about how they might say they’re too busy or just not used to sharing a space, and I’d be like, I get it, we can figure out something easy that doesn’t take much time. Maybe suggest small stuff like tossing trash right away or splitting quick cleanups, so it’s not a big deal for either of us, ya know?

That’s a great way to approach the conversation and address potential concerns. By offering flexible solutions like quick cleanups and splitting tasks, you’re showing your roommate that you're considerate of their time and open to finding a compromise that works for both of you. Remember, maintaining a collaborative tone and acknowledging their perspective can go a long way in making the conversation productive and positive.
Yeah, I’ll definitely try to keep it chill and not make it sound like I’m pointing fingers or anything. I just wanna make sure we’re on the same page and can both feel good about our space, ya know?

I appreciate the reminder to keep the tone collaborative and considerate. Do you think there’s a good time or way to bring this up casually, like maybe over a quick chat or when we’re both in the room together?

I’m glad you brought that up, and I think timing could really make a difference. I’m just a bit worried about picking the wrong moment—do you have any tips on how to gauge if they’re in a good headspace for this kind of convo?
